**Answer.** The desired set of rational numbers is $\{\frac{n+1}{n} : n \in \mathbb{Z}, n \neq 0\}$.

Let $Z$ be the set of rational numbers $q$ such that for any $f \in \mathcal{F}$, there exists some $z \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(z) = qz$. Further, let

$$
S = \left\{ \frac{n+1}{n} : n \in \mathbb{Z}, n \neq 0 \right\}
$$

We prove that $Z = S$ by showing the two inclusions $S \subseteq Z$ and $Z \subseteq S$.

We first prove that $S \subseteq Z$. Let $f \in \mathcal{F}$ and let $P(x, y)$ denote the relation $f(x + f(y)) = f(x) + f(y)$. Let $f(0) = c$. $P(0, 0)$ gives $f(c) = 2c$. We claim that $f(kc) = (k + 1)c$ for all $k \ge 1$. We prove this by induction on $k$. Base case $k = 1$ is already proved. Assume this is true for some $k$, then $P(0, kc)$ gives $f((k + 1)c) = (k + 2)c$, as required. Thus the claim is proved.

We now claim that $f(-kc) = (-k + 1)c$ for every integer $k \ge 1$. Indeed, $P(-kc, kc)$ gives

$$
f(c) = f(-kc) + (k+1)c \implies f(-kc) = (-k+1)c
$$

Thus $f(kc) = (k + 1)c = \frac{k+1}{k} \cdot (kc)$ is true for every integer $k \neq 0$, so $\frac{k+1}{k} \in Z$ for every $k \neq 0$. Thus $S \subseteq Z$, as required.

Now we prove $Z \subseteq S$. Let $p$ be a rational number outside $S$. We want to prove $p \notin Z$ by constructing an $f \in \mathcal{F}$ with $f(z) \neq pq$ for every $z \in \mathbb{R}$. The strategy is to first construct a function $g : [0, 1) \to \mathbb{Z}$, and then define $f(x) = g(\{x\}) + \lfloor x \rfloor$. This $f \in \mathcal{F}$; indeed:

$$
\begin{align*}
f(x + f(y)) &= g(\{x + f(y)\}) + \lfloor x + f(y) \rfloor \\
&= g(\{x + g(\{y\}) + \lfloor y \rfloor\}) + \lfloor x + g(\{y\}) + \lfloor y \rfloor \rfloor \\
&= g(\{x\}) + \lfloor x \rfloor + g(\{y\}) + \lfloor y \rfloor \\
&= f(x) + f(y)
\end{align*}
$$

where we used that $g$ only takes integer values.

**Claim 1** For every $\alpha \in [0, 1)$, there exists an $m \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that

$$
m + n \neq p(\alpha + n)
$$

for every $n \in \mathbb{Z}$.

*Proof.* If $p = 1$, we can just take $m = 1$ since $\alpha < 1$. If $p \neq 1$, the claim is equivalent to the existence of an integer $m$ such that

$$
\frac{m - p\alpha}{p - 1}
$$

is not an integer. Assume the contrary. That would mean that

$$
\frac{m - p\alpha}{p - 1} \text{ and } \frac{(m + 1) - p\alpha}{p - 1}
$$

are both integers, and so is their difference. The latter is equal to $\frac{1}{p-1}$. But since we assumed $p \neq S$, $\frac{1}{p-1} \neq \mathbb{Z}$, contradiction! $\square$

Define $g: [0, 1) \to \mathbb{Z}$ by $g(\alpha) = m$ for any integer $m$ satisfying Claim 1 for $\alpha$. Then $f(z) \neq pz$ if and only if

$$
g(\{z\}) + \lfloor z \rfloor \neq p(\{z\} + \lfloor z \rfloor)
$$

But this is guaranteed by the construction of the function $g$. We conclude that $p \notin \mathbb{Z}$. Thus $Z \subseteq S$, as required. $\square$

The following proof is due to ideas from Ananda Bhaduri in the TST. The proof has been revised and rewritten by the Problem Selection Committee.

We give an alternate proof for $Z \subseteq S$. Take a rational $p/q \notin S$ (with $\text{gcd}(p, q) = 1$). Note that $p \neq 0$ as $0 \in S$.

Call a real number $x$ **bad** if $\lceil x \rceil = p/qx$. We define an equivalence relation $x \sim y$ iff $x - y \in \mathbb{Z}$. Choose a prime $N > |p| + |q|$. Define

$$
f(x) = \begin{cases} \lceil x \rceil + N & \text{if } x \sim z \text{ for some bad } z \\ \lceil x \rceil & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}
$$

We claim that $f \in \mathcal{F}$. Indeed, $f$ only takes integer values, and $x + n \sim z$ for some bad $y$ iff $x \sim z$. Therefore

$$
f(x + f(y)) = \lceil x + f(y) \rceil + N = \lceil x \rceil + N + f(y) = f(x) + f(y)
$$

if $x \sim z$ for some bad $z$, and

$$
f(x + f(y)) = \lceil x + f(y) \rceil = \lceil x \rceil + f(y) = f(x) + f(y)
$$

otherwise.

Assume FTSOC $f(x) = p/qx$. If $f(x) = \lceil x \rceil$, then $x$ is bad by definition, so $f(x) = \lceil x \rceil + N$, contradiction! Hence $x \sim z$ for some bad $z$, i.e., some $z = \frac{qn}{p}$ for some $n \in \mathbb{Z}$ with $\lceil \frac{qn}{p} \rceil = n$. Therefore $x = \frac{qn}{p} + m$, and so

$$
n + \frac{pm}{q} = f(x) = n + m + N \\ \implies pm = q(m + N)
$$

If $N \mid m$, then writing $m = aN$ we get $p/q = \frac{a+1}{a} \in S$, contradiction! So $N \nmid m$; then $\text{gcd}(m+N, m) = 1$ as $N$ is prime. Therefore $m+N \mid p$. Since $\text{gcd}(p, q) = 1$, $p \mid m+N \implies |p| = |m+N| \implies |q| = |m|$.

$$
\implies |N| \leq |m + N| + |m| = |p| + |q|
$$

Contradiction! Therefore $f(x) \neq p/qx$ for any $x$, so $p/q \notin \mathbb{Z}$ for any $p/q \notin S$. This gives us $Z \subseteq S$, as required. $\square$
